message: Hello, DVLA Customer Services.
How can I assist you today?
Yeah, hi.
I received a letter saying I owe a fine for not declaring my car off the road,
but I'm pretty sure I did that already.
I understand your concern.
Could you provide me with your vehicle's registration number, so I can look into this further?
JK51 VMZ
Okay, let me check the records for that registration number.
I apologize, but our records indicate that you have not declared a Statutory Off Road Notification, or SORN, for this vehicle.
That can't be right.
I distinctly remember doing that online last year when I took it off the road for repairs.
I understand your frustration, but without an active SORN, you are liable for the fine.
Could you provide me with the details of when and how you believe you submitted the SORN?
I don't have the exact date, but it was sometime in June or July of last year.
I did it through the website, like I've done before.
Hmm, I'm not seeing any record of a SORN submission for your vehicle in our system during that timeframe.
Are you absolutely certain you completed the process correctly?
Yes, I'm positive!
This is ridiculous. I shouldn't have to pay a fine because of your system's mistake.
Sir, I understand your frustration, but without proof of a successfully submitted SORN, I cannot waive the fine.
Is there any documentation you have that shows you completed the process?
No, I don't have any documentation.
I just followed the online steps like normal.
In that case, I'm afraid there is little I can do. The fine stands unless you can provide evidence that a SORN was properly submitted.
This is unbelievable.
You're basically calling me a liar and accusing me of not doing something I clearly did.
I apologize if I've caused any offense, that is not my intention at all.
I'm simply going by the information in our system, which does not show an active SORN for your vehicle.
Well your system is wrong then, isn't it?
I demand that this fine be waived and my record updated to show the SORN.
Unfortunately, without documented proof, I do not have the authority to waive the fine or update records.
However, I can escalate this issue to a supervisor for further review if you'd like.
Yes, please do that.
This is absolutely ridiculous customer service.
Very well, let me transfer you to a supervisor who can look into this further.
One moment please.
Hello, this is Susan, a DVLA supervisor.
I understand there is an issue regarding a SORN declaration and fine.
How can I assist you today?
Yes, hello.
I've been trying to explain to your agent that I properly declared my vehicle off the road last year,
but your records seem to be incorrect...
I see, let me pull up the details here...
Mr. Johnson, is that correct?
No, it's Taylor. David Taylor.
My apologies, Mr. Taylor.
I have the details regarding the SORN issue and outstanding fine for your vehicle registration JK51 VMZ.
Yes, that's the one.
As I was trying to explain, I definitely submitted that SORN notice when I took the car off the road last summer.
I understand your position, Mr. Taylor.
While I cannot find record of a successfully processed SORN declaration,
I can see where there may have been an issue with the online submission based on the notes here.
Finally, someone who actually listens!
So what needs to happen to get this sorted out?
For situations like this, I'd recommend submitting a formal appeal along with any documentation you may have,
such as confirmation screenshots from the website when you attempted the SORN last year.
I don't have any documentation like that.
As I said, I just followed the normal online process.
I understand, Mr. Taylor.
In that case, I would still recommend you submit a formal appeal explaining the situation in detail.
Our review team can then investigate further and make a fair determination on the standing of the fine.
Okay, fine. I'll submit an appeal,
but this whole situation has been extremely frustrating.
You're absolutely right, this has clearly caused you a significant inconvenience, and I apologize for that.
I assure you, your appeal will be given a thorough review.
Let me provide you the details for submitting that.
...And Mr. Taylor, I've also made a note on your account regarding this issue, so it will be referenced during the appeal review process.
Alright, thank you for actually taking the time to listen and escalate this properly.
You're very welcome, Mr. Taylor. We strive to provide exceptional service,
and I'm sorry we initially fell short in resolving this for you.
Please let me know if any other issues arise during the appeal process.
I will. Thanks again.
You're welcome. Have a great rest of your day.
